intro: Ranunculus scapigerus var. decurvus, commonly known as the hooked buttercup, is a herbaceous perennial native to the western United States. It features basal leaves that are deeply lobed and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are upright and often branched. The flowers are yellow with five petals and are typically borne on long, slender peduncles. This variety is characterized by its distinctive hooked sepals that curve downward, giving it its common name. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in meadows and woodland areas.
